Risk factors like poor oral hygiene, smoking, and diabetes worsen progression from peri-implant mucositis to peri-implantitis. Professional maintenance and patient education on preventive measures support peri-implant health. Regular recall visits aid in monitoring marginal bone loss and clinical parameters.

Interdisciplinary approaches involving periodontists and dental hygienists improve treatment outcomes. Non-surgical treatment like mechanical debridement targets early stages, while surgical options address advanced bone resorption. Long-term prognosis depends on addressing host response and pathogen bacteria effectively.

Bacterial Biofilm Formation

Implant surfaces develop thick biofilms within 48 hours, harbouring red-complex bacteria such as Porphyromonas gingivalis, Tannerella forsythia, and Treponema denticola. Biofilm maturation starts with pellicle formation in 1 minute, early colonizers in 4 hours, and late colonizers by 7 days. This leads to plaque accumulation on implant threads and abutment connections.

Biofilms on implants reach higher densities than on natural teeth due to surface roughness and design factors. This promotes bacterial infection and dysbiosis, increasing risk of peri-implant disease. Platform switching and implant design influence biofilm formation and osseointegration.

Practical examples include patients with poor oral hygiene showing rapid soft tissue inflammation around dental implants. Preventive measures like professional cleaning reduce biofilm on implant surfaces. Patient education on brushing techniques helps control plaque accumulation.

Microbiological analysis reveals pathogen bacteria thriving in these environments. Early intervention with mechanical debridement prevents progression to inflammation. Regular monitoring of pocket depth supports implant stability and success.

Host Immune Response

IL-1β levels rise sharply in peri-implantitis sites compared to healthy tissue, driving RANKL/OPG imbalance towards osteoclast activation. Key cytokines include IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α, and MMP-8, fuelling inflammation. Neutrophil extracellular traps, or NETosis, contribute to tissue destruction around implants.

CytokineRole in Peri-implantitis
IL-1βTriggers acute inflammation and bone resorption
IL-6Amplifies immune cell recruitment
TNF-αPromotes matrix degradation
MMP-8Breaks down connective tissue

Research suggests these inflammatory cytokines disrupt host response in peri-implant crevices. Patients with diabetes show exaggerated responses, worsening gingival inflammation. Antibiotics and laser therapy target this immune overreaction in non-surgical treatment.

Experts recommend monitoring bleeding on probing for early signs. Recall visits allow assessment of immune response via clinical parameters. Addressing risk factors like smoking improves outcomes and implant survival.

Bone Loss Mechanisms

Vertical bone loss progresses steadily, involving osteoclast activation via Wnt/β-catenin disruption and titanium particle-induced osteolysis. Three main mechanisms drive this: inflammatory osteoclastogenesis, micro-motion induced fibrosis from low torque values, and corrosion products from alloys like Ti6Al4V releasing metal ions. This differs from periodontitis, showing a steeper 45° angle pattern on radiographs.

Inflammatory osteoclastogenesis ramps up with elevated RANKL, targeting alveolar and crestal bone. Micro-motion below stable torque compromises osseointegration, leading to implant mobility. Corrosion contributes to chronic irritation and marginal bone loss.

  • Osteoclastogenesis: Cytokine-driven bone resorption
  • Micro-motion: Fibrosis from poor implant stability
  • Corrosion: Metal ions triggering osteolysis

Cone beam CT and digital radiography detect vertical and horizontal bone loss early. Regenerative therapy and surgical treatment aim to halt progression. Patient cases with uncontrolled diabetes highlight faster bone loss rates.

Preventive measures include optimal implant placement and professional maintenance. Staging classification guides severity grading and complication management. Long-term success relies on controlling these mechanisms through interdisciplinary care.

Clinical Signs and Symptoms

Diagnosis requires ≥3 sites BOP + PD≥6mm + radiographic BL≥2mm. These criteria from the 2017 case definition help clinicians identify peri-implantitis accurately. In many cases, suppuration appears on probing.

Patient progression often starts with asymptomatic bleeding, advances to pain, then suppuration, and finally implant mobility. This sequence signals worsening bone loss around dental implants. Early detection prevents implant failure.

Combined parameters show high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis. Clinicians use bleeding on probing, probing depth, and radiographs together. Regular checks catch peri-implant disease before severe damage.

Experts recommend monitoring plaque accumulation and soft tissue inflammation. Patients with risk factors like poor oral hygiene face faster progression. Professional maintenance supports implant success.

Early Indicators

Bleeding on probing at ≥30% sites + PD 4-5mm identifies cases progressing to peri-implantitis within 2 years. These signs point to initial peri-implant mucositis. Prompt action halts advancement to bone loss.

Key early signs include:

  • BOP at >30% sites, linked to higher odds of disease.
  • PD≥4mm, a sensitive measure of pocket depth.
  • Plaque score>20%, showing bacterial buildup.
  • Mucosal recession>1mm, indicating gingival inflammation.
  • BL>0.5mm/year, early radiographic bone loss.

Clinicians track these via recall visits. Patients should report loose sensation early. Preventive measures like better hygiene slow progression.

Timeline shows inflammation leading to osseointegration issues over months. Use digital radiography for monitoring. Dental hygienists guide patient education on plaque control.

Advanced Manifestations

Stage III peri-implantitis shows ≥3mm vertical BL, suppuration at many sites, and ISQ<65. These features mark severe disease progression. Implants risk mobility and failure.

ITI staging classifies severity:

  • Stage I: <3mm bone loss, mild defects.
  • Stage II: 3-5mm loss, moderate involvement.
  • Stage III: >5mm + complex defects, high mobility.

Mobility grade 1 means >50μm horizontal shift. Pus volume needs quantification during exams. Pain often exceeds VAS>5/10, affecting daily life.

Treatment shifts to surgical options like debridement or regenerative therapy. Periodontists assess cone beam CT for defects. Long-term prognosis improves with early stage intervention.

Patient-Reported Symptoms

In advanced cases, many report spontaneous pain, chewing sensitivity, and prosthesis mobility sensation. These symptoms correlate with disease stage. Patients notice changes during eating or brushing.

SymptomPrevalence in Advanced Cases
PainCommon, often persistent
SwellingFrequent around implant
MobilitySensed in prosthesis
Food impactionTroublesome daily
Foul tasteLinked to infection

Symptoms worsen with bone resorption and suppuration. Poor oral hygiene or smoking accelerates this. Patients should seek care for throbbing pain.

Interdisciplinary teams, including prosthodontists, address complaints. Non-surgical treatment like antibiotics helps mild reports. Regular evaluations track symptom relief and implant stability.

Diagnosis

The 2017 consensus requires clinical criteria of probing depth (PD) ≥6mm plus bleeding on probing (BOP) combined with radiographic evidence of ≥2mm bone loss (BL) beyond expected for definitive peri-implantitis diagnosis. Multimodal diagnosis integrates clinical probing, digital radiography, and microbiological sampling to assess inflammation, bone loss, and bacterial infection around dental implants. This approach improves accuracy in detecting peri-implant disease progression.

Clinical examination identifies soft tissue inflammation and pocket depth, while radiographs reveal marginal bone loss and defect morphology. Microbiological analysis detects pathogens like Porphyromonas gingivalis, aiding in confirming bacterial infection. Experts recommend combining these for reliable diagnosis of implant failure risks.

Early detection through this method supports timely intervention, distinguishing peri-implant mucositis from peri-implantitis. Patient factors such as poor oral hygiene or smoking influence disease severity. Regular recall visits enhance diagnostic precision.

Combined parameters offer high diagnostic accuracy, guiding treatment from non-surgical debridement to surgical options. This structured process ensures comprehensive evaluation of osseointegration status and long-term implant survival.

Clinical Examination Protocols

Examine 6 sites per implant using a 0.2N Florida probe: record PD, recession, BOP, suppuration, and plaque within 24hrs post-hygiene. This step-by-step protocol begins with a plastic probe at 0.2N force to avoid damaging the implant surface. Follow with a 6-point chart for thorough assessment around titanium implants.

Record BOP within 30 seconds post-probe to gauge gingival inflammation accurately. Collect suppuration samples if present, indicating advanced infection. Perform a mobility test with 2kg horizontal force to check implant stability.

Use probe types like TPS or 3-in-1 for consistent measurements, minimising examiner variability. Document plaque accumulation and soft tissue inflammation to identify risk factors such as poor oral hygiene. These steps support early detection of peri-implant disease.

For example, in a patient with diabetes, note increased BOP at multiple sites as a sign of disease progression. Professional maintenance during recall visits reinforces these protocols. This approach aids periodontists and hygienists in staging peri-implantitis severity.

Radiographic Assessment

CBCT detects intra-bony defects with greater sensitivity than periapical views; measure marginal bone level from fixture shoulder with 0.2mm precision. Follow an imaging hierarchy: panoramic for screening, periapical for 2D quantification, and CBCT for 3D defect morphology. This evaluates radiographic bone loss in peri-implantitis cases.

Establish baseline radiographs 1 year post-loading, then annual checks to track vertical and horizontal BL ratios. Horizontal loss often appears as crestal bone resorption around implant threads. Vertical defects signal more severe progression toward implant failure.

Digital radiography aids in quantifying alveolar bone changes and periapical radiolucency. For instance, platform switching designs may show less marginal bone loss. CBCT reveals furcation involvement or dehiscence not visible in 2D images.

Interdisciplinary teams, including oral surgeons, use these assessments for treatment planning. Combine with clinical parameters for full evaluation of bone resorption and host response. Regular radiographic evaluation supports preventive measures and long-term prognosis.

Probing Depth Measurements

Healthy peri-implant PD measures 3.0±1.1mm; disease threshold is ≥6mm + BOP at ≥3 sites. Use a controlled technique with the probe inserted parallel to the implant surface at a 60-degree angle to avoid the false pocket effect from improper angulation. This ensures accurate clinical attachment loss assessment.

Measure at six sites per implant, recording the deepest reading per area. Factors like implant design and surface roughness influence baseline PD. Bleeding on probing indicates inflammation from biofilm formation or dysbiosis.

Inter-examiner reliability improves with standardised probes, supporting consistent diagnosis. In practice, a patient with cement remnants may show deepened pockets due to bacterial harbouring. Track changes over recall visits to monitor disease progression.

Thresholds guide differentiation from periodontitis or peri-implant mucositis. Combine with suppuration and mobility tests for comprehensive evaluation. This method enables dental professionals to recommend mechanical debridement or antibiotics early.

Risk Factors

Multivariate analysis identifies 8 risk factors explaining 67% of peri-implantitis variance. These divide into patient-related and implant-related domains. Patient factors often drive inflammation and bone loss, while implant issues promote plaque accumulation and bacterial infection.

Guidelines highlight a 3.7x higher risk when multiple factors combine. For instance, smokers with poor oral hygiene face rapid disease progression. Early screening separates these domains to guide preventive measures and professional maintenance.

Patient risks stem from host responses like immune dysregulation, leading to gingival inflammation and probing depth increases. Implant risks involve design flaws causing marginal bone loss. Addressing both improves implant success and reduces implant failure rates.

Radiographic evaluation and clinical parameters, such as bleeding on probing, help monitor these factors. Interdisciplinary approaches with periodontists and dental hygienists enhance early detection. Patient education on recall visits supports long-term peri-implant health.

Patient-Related Factors

Patient factors account for 58% disease variance: prior periodontitis (OR=4.9), poor oral hygiene (OR=3.4), smoking (OR=2.9). History of periodontitis tops the list with the highest relative risk, promoting similar bacterial infection around titanium implants. It fosters biofilm formation and soft tissue inflammation.

Smoking more than 10 cigarettes daily ranks second, impairing osseointegration and increasing suppuration risk. Uncontrolled diabetes follows, with elevated blood sugar fuelling inflammatory cytokines and osteoclast activity. Low compliance, like skipping recall visits, completes the top risks.

Use this patient screening checklist before implant placement:

  • Assess periodontitis history via probing depth and radiographic bone loss.
  • Evaluate smoking habits and offer cessation advice.
  • Check diabetes control through recent HbA1c levels.
  • Gauge oral hygiene with plaque index and bleeding on probing scores.

Poor compliance shows in inconsistent brushing or flossing, leading to plaque accumulation. Experts recommend tailored patient education to boost adherence. Regular professional maintenance curbs disease progression in at-risk individuals.

Implant-Related Factors

Implant factors contribute 42% risk: surface roughness greater than 2μm (OR=2.8), lack of platform-switching (OR=2.1). These modifiable elements affect implant surface and abutment connection, encouraging pathogen bacteria like Porphyromonas gingivalis. Placement errors account for 15% of cases, causing uneven load and bone resorption.

Surface roughness beyond optimal levels boosts bacterial adhesion on implant threads. Without platform switching, crestal bone experiences excess stress, leading to vertical bone loss. Cement remnants from restorations trap debris, worsening pocket depth and clinical attachment loss.

Mitigate risks with these strategies:

  • Select implants with controlled surface roughness for better peri-implant mucositis prevention.
  • Incorporate platform switching to preserve alveolar bone.
  • Ensure precise implant placement using cone beam CT for alignment.
  • Avoid excess cement through subgingival margins and careful prosthodontic design.

Implant stability at insertion, checked via torque value, prevents early mobility. Oral surgeons should prioritise these during surgery. Combined with non-surgical treatment like mechanical debridement, they support implant survival and reduce complication management needs.

Treatment Approaches

Success rates vary across treatments, with non-surgical therapy showing around 45% clinical attachment level reduction, surgical approaches achieving 70% defect fill, and antibiotics providing an extra 40% probing pocket depth reduction. The 2023 ITI guidelines outline a clear treatment ladder starting with non-surgical methods, progressing to surgical options, and reserving explantation for Stage IV cases with extensive bone loss. This algorithm prioritises preserving dental implants while addressing peri-implantitis progression.

Treatment begins with patient education on poor oral hygiene and risk factors like smoking or diabetes. Professionals assess probing depth, bleeding on probing, and radiographic bone loss to stage the disease. Regular recall visits help monitor inflammation and plaque accumulation.

For mild cases, mechanical debridement targets bacterial infection. Advanced peri-implant disease may need regenerative therapy or implant removal if osseointegration fails. An interdisciplinary approach involving periodontists and hygienists improves outcomes.

Long-term success depends on professional maintenance and patient compliance. Early detection prevents implant failure, ensuring better implant survival rates.

Non-Surgical Therapies

Non-surgical therapy achieves about 1.5mm pocket depth reduction and 40% bleeding on probing elimination at 12 months. These methods focus on mechanical debridement to disrupt biofilm on the implant surface. They suit early peri-implant mucositis or mild peri-implantitis with shallow defects.

Common approaches include four key methods. Ultrasonic scaling with air polishing removes plaque effectively. Er:YAG laser therapy targets bacteria without damaging titanium implants. CHX gel application reduces gingival inflammation, while photodynamic therapy uses light-activated agents against pathogens.

  • Week 1-2: Initial ultrasonic debridement and air polishing sessions.
  • Week 4-6: Laser or CHX gel adjuncts, with oral hygiene instructions.
  • Month 3-12: Monthly recalls to monitor probing depth and suppuration.

Patients should avoid smoking and maintain brushing around implant threads. This timeline supports soft tissue inflammation resolution and prevents disease progression.

Surgical Interventions

Surgical access yields about 2.5mm clinical attachment level gain compared to 1.1mm from non-surgical methods, with 65% defect resolution. These protocols address moderate to advanced peri-implantitis with radiographic bone loss. Success varies by defect type, favouring intra-bony over supracrestal lesions.

Three main surgical options exist. Access flap with debridement exposes the implant for thorough cleaning. Resective therapy uses osteoplasty to reshape bone and eliminate pockets. Reconstructive approaches apply grafts for bone regeneration in contained defects.

  • Intra-bony defects respond well to reconstruction, promoting osseointegration.
  • Supracrestal defects often need resective methods to reduce pocket depth.
  • Post-op care includes antibiotics and chlorhexidine rinses for two weeks.

Cone beam CT aids planning, assessing vertical and horizontal bone loss. Periodontists evaluate implant stability before proceeding, aiming for long-term peri-implant health.

Systemic Antibiotics

Amoxicillin 500mg plus metronidazole 400mg three times daily for seven days as an adjunct yields about 1.2mm additional probing pocket depth reduction. These regimens target pathogen bacteria like Porphyromonas gingivalis in peri-implantitis. They complement debridement for persistent infection.

Standard options include three regimens. Amoxicillin/metronidazole combination for broad coverage. Azithromycin 500mg daily for three days for shorter courses. Clindamycin serves allergy cases, addressing gram-positive pathogens.

Microbiological analysis shows reductions in key species, supporting host response. Monitor resistance through post-treatment cultures during recalls. Combine with patient education on oral microbiota dysbiosis.

Prescribe based on suppuration and pocket depth. Advise completing the course to prevent implant failure. Regular follow-ups track inflammation and bone resorption.

Prevention Strategies

Structured maintenance reduces peri-implantitis incidence by targeting patient compliance and professional interventions. This approach forms a prevention pyramid with layered steps to protect dental implants from plaque accumulation and bacterial infection.

Level 1 starts with patient daily oral hygiene, using tools like interdental brushes and rinses to minimise biofilm formation around implant threads. Level 2 involves professional maintenance every 3-6 months, including debridement and monitoring for bleeding on probing or probing depth increases.

Level 3 focuses on risk-based implant selection, considering factors like smoking, diabetes, and implant design to lower risks of marginal bone loss. Finally, recall compliance tracking with apps ensures consistent follow-up, preventing disease progression from peri-implant mucositis to full peri-implantitis.

Experts recommend this pyramid for implant success, combining patient education with regular radiographic evaluation to detect early inflammation or bone resorption.

Oral Hygiene Protocols

Interdental brushes and water flossers outperform brushing alone in controlling plaque around dental implants. A structured 7-point hygiene protocol enables patients to maintain peri-implant health and reduce risks of gingival inflammation.

Begin with a single-tufted brush to clean implant threads thoroughly. Next, select interdental brushes using a size chart to fit snugly without trauma, followed by a water flosser at moderate pressure for subgingival plaque removal.

Incorporate a 0.2% chlorhexidine rinse twice daily for antimicrobial action against pathogens like Porphyromonas gingivalis. Finish with rubber cup polishing during home care to smooth surfaces and limit bacterial adhesion.

Track compliance with a dedicated app to monitor brushing frequency and technique. This routine supports osseointegration and early detection of soft tissue inflammation, key to preventing implant failure.

Regular Maintenance Visits

Frequent supportive periodontal therapy slows peri-implant disease progression effectively. Risk-based recall intervals tailor visits to individual needs, ensuring timely intervention for probing depth or suppuration.

For low-risk patients, schedule visits every 6-12 months with basic checks for plaque and bleeding on probing. Moderate-risk cases need visits every 4-6 months, while high-risk patients, such as smokers or those with diabetes, require quarterly reviews.

Risk LevelRecall IntervalKey Checks
Lowq6-12 monthsPlaque score, mobility
Moderateq4-6 monthsProbing depth, radiograph
Highq3 monthsBone loss, suppuration

Monitor progression with thresholds like pocket depth increase over 1mm, prompting immediate referral. Annual radiographs aid in spotting radiographic bone loss early, supporting long-term implant survival.

Material and Design Selection

Platform-switched implants demonstrate reduced marginal bone loss compared to traditional designs over time. Selecting materials and designs based on evidence minimises risks of inflammation and bone resorption around titanium implants.

Opt for platform switching to preserve crestal bone by shifting the abutment connection inward. Laser-modified surfaces with controlled roughness enhance soft tissue attachment and resist bacterial biofilm.

Choose tissue-level implants to reduce cement remnants and pocket depth issues. Narrow diameter implants under 3.3mm suit sites with limited bone, lowering mechanical stress and disease risk.

Design FeatureBenefitExample Use
Platform switchingPreserves alveolar bonePosterior implants
Laser-modified surfaceImproves stabilityImmediate placement
Tissue-levelReduces inflammationAnterior aesthetics
Narrow diameterMinimises traumaThin ridges

Frequently Asked Questions

What is peri-implantitis?

Peri-implantitis is a destructive inflammatory process affecting the soft and hard tissues surrounding dental implants, similar to periodontitis but specifically around implants. It involves progressive bone loss and pocket formation due to bacterial infection.

What causes peri-implantitis?

Peri-implantitis is primarily caused by plaque accumulation and poor oral hygiene, leading to bacterial infection. Risk factors include smoking, diabetes, previous periodontitis, and improper implant placement or loading.

What are the symptoms of peri-implantitis?

Symptoms of peri-implantitis include bleeding on probing, increased probing pocket depths, suppuration (pus), gingival swelling, pain, implant mobility, and radiographic evidence of progressive bone loss around the implant.

How is peri-implantitis diagnosed?

Peri-implantitis is diagnosed through clinical examination (probing depths> 5mm with bleeding), radiographic imaging showing bone loss> 2mm beyond the first year post-loading, and sometimes microbial testing for pathogens.

What is the treatment for peri-implantitis?

Treatment for peri-implantitis ranges from non-surgical (scaling, debridement, antibiotics) for early stages to surgical interventions like flap surgery, bone grafting, or laser therapy; advanced cases may require implant removal.

How can peri-implantitis be prevented?

Peri-implantitis can be prevented by maintaining excellent oral hygiene, regular professional cleanings, quitting smoking, managing systemic diseases like diabetes, and ensuring proper implant design and placement by qualified professionals.
